title: Guy Stéphan
text:
Guy Stéphan (born 17 October 1956) is a French professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> manager who works as assistant coach of the <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France national team</a>.
Playing career.
Stéphan trained in the <a href="Perros-Guirec">Perros-Guirec</a> club. In 1976, he was spotted by <a href="En%20Avant%20de%20Guingamp">En Avant de Guingamp</a>, a D3 club where he began a promising career at age 19. The club climbed in D2 in 1977. In 1980 he signed with <a href="Stade%20Rennais%20F.C.">Rennes</a>, still in D2, while leading head-on and successful studies of physical education teacher (which is worth new selections in France university team).
After two years at <a href="Le%20Havre%20AC">Le Havre AC</a> and <a href="US%20Orl%C3%A9ans">US Orléans</a>, he joined <a href="Stade%20Malherbe%20Caen">Stade Malherbe Caen</a> in 1985, which aimed to promote to Division 1. A year later, a car accident put an early end to his career, at 29.
Coaching career.
Stéphan immediately decided to become a coach. Stade Malherbe Caen proposed to him to direct their reserve team for the 1987–88 season. He coached <a href="FC%20Montceau%20Bourgogne">FC Montceau Bourgogne</a>, in the <a href="1988%E2%80%9389%20French%20Division%202">1988–89</a> season, then <a href="Annecy%20FC">Annecy FC</a>. Stéphan made his classes there until 1992, when <a href="Raymond%20Domenech">Raymond Domenech</a>, then coach of <a href="Olympique%20Lyon">Olympique Lyon</a>, called him as assistant coach. He stayed with <a href="Jean%20Tigana">Jean Tigana</a> for two years, before taking the reins of Olympique Lyon in 1995.
His career then led him to <a href="FC%20Girondins%20de%20Bordeaux">Bordeaux</a>. For four and a half years, while training French coaches, he coached the 17-year-old French team and the A 'team. He was assistant to <a href="Roger%20Lemerre">Roger Lemerre</a> and he won the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202000">UEFA Euro 2000</a> in Netherlands and <a href="2001%20FIFA%20Confederations%20Cup">2001 FIFA Confederations Cup</a> in Japan.
In October 2002, he signed a contract with <a href="Senegal%20national%20football%20team">Senegal</a> after their impressive performance in <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a>. He reached the quarter-final of <a href="2004%20African%20Cup%20of%20Nations">2004 African Cup of Nations</a> hosted by <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>. Nevertheless, he was relieved of his duties in June 2005 after only two defeats in official matches in 30 months. He later became assistant to Jean Tigana at <a href="Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F%20J.K.">Beşiktaş</a>, where he served until June 2007.
In May 2009, he was hired by <a href="Didier%20Deschamps">Didier Deschamps</a> as an assistant coach at <a href="Olympique%20de%20Marseille">Olympique de Marseille</a>. In July 2012, he followed Deschamps to the French national team as an assistant. He has been a part of coaching staffs that have led France to the quarterfinal of the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2014 FIFA World Cup</a> in Brazil, the final of <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016">UEFA Euro 2016</a> as the host nation, and then won the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a> in Russia.
Personal life.
Guy Stéphan's sons <a href="Guillaume%20St%C3%A9phan">Guillaume</a> and <a href="Julien%20St%C3%A9phan">Julien Stéphan</a> are also former footballers and Julien has similarly become a football manager.
